dt: {bc}to satisfy the needs or wishes of

dt.t: laws by which the material wants of men are {it}supplied{/it}

dt: {bc}to furnish (organs, tissues, or cells) with a vital element (such as blood or nerve fibers)
{bc}to serve as a supply in (a church or pulpit)
{bc}to serve as a supply or substitute

et: Middle English {it}supplien{/it} "to fill up, accomplish, discharge (an office)," borrowed from Middle French {it}soupplier{/it} "to add what is lacking to" (also {it}souppleer, suploier{/it} "to make up for [a lack, deficiency]," {it}suppleer a, soupplir{/it} "to replace"), going back to Latin {it}supplēre{/it} "to fill up, complete, raise (a military unit, crew) to its full complement, make good a deficiency in," from {it}sub-{/it} {et_link|sub-|sub-} + {it}plēre{/it} "to fill" {ma}{mat|full:1|}{/ma}

Though the French verb receives its semantic start with Latin {it}supplēre,{/it} none of the great variety of formal outcomes appear to be directly traceable to it. Variants such as {it}suploier{/it} and {it}soupplier{/it} have evidently been crossed with outcomes of {it}supplicāre{/it} "to sue for forgiveness, {et_link|supplicate|supplicate}" (see also {et_link|suppliant:1|suppliant:1}). The form {it}suppleer,{/it} which may be directly behind Modern French {it}suppléer,{/it} appears to have been both latinized (after {it}supplēre{/it}) and conformed to verbs such as {it}créer.{/it} The variant {it}soupplir{/it} suggests the general Romance re-formation {it}*supplīre{/it} (compare Old Occitan and Spanish {it}suplir,{/it} Italian {it}sopperire{/it}).
shortdef: to make available for use : provide
to satisfy the needs or wishes of
